logs.name: QueenOfChaos
logs.text: How do you know he is not proud of his cakes? Artists do not take pride in their work? Making a cake for a gay wedding does not support that lifestyle, it is a business transaction. Period. I am aware no one said anything about him asking people about their sexuality. I am sorry that was hard for you to understand. Is he going to ask everyone that comes in if the cake is for a gay wedding? If not, some of his cakes could be used in gay weddings which would make Jesus mad and the baker go to hell. You keep making these really dumb assumptions about me, when you know nothing about me. I am not confused, you are rude. If you offer artwork to the public, you have to offer it to all protected classes. Why would black people be discriminated against? Precedent. Ridiculous? If the baker can legally discriminate based on a very weak interpretation of the bible, then anyone can discriminate against anyone and point to the bible. Satanists can discriminate against Christians...

logs.name: DarkShadow333
logs.text: @QueenOfChaos, you're missing the point, sweetheart. It's not about the cake, it's about the principle. If a baker doesn't want to make a cake for a gay wedding, that's their right. It's their business, their art, and their choice. You can't force someone to create something they don't believe in. And don't give me that 'protected classes' nonsense. This isn't about race or gender, it's about a choice. And if you think Jesus is going to be mad about a cake, you're the one who needs to re-read your bible. 🙄

logs.name: GoldenYears66
logs.text: @DarkShadow333, you're the one missing the point, my friend. It's not about the baker's beliefs, it's about the law. If you open a business to the public, you can't pick and choose who you serve based on your personal beliefs. That's discrimination, plain and simple. And don't give me that 'choice' nonsense. Being gay isn't a choice, and neither is being black or a woman. It's about time we stop using the bible as an excuse to discriminate. If we start letting people choose who they serve based on their beliefs, where does it end? Next thing you know, we'll have businesses refusing service to interracial couples or single mothers. Is that what you want? And don't you dare tell me to re-read my bible. I've read it plenty, and I know that Jesus taught love and acceptance, not hate and discrimination.

logs.name: DarkShadow333
logs.text: @GoldenYears66, oh please, spare me the sanctimonious lecture. You're just another snowflake who can't handle a different opinion. It's not discrimination when it's a matter of artistic expression. If a gay couple wants a cake, they can go to one of the countless bakeries that would be happy to serve them. But don't you dare tell a baker that they have to create something that goes against their beliefs. That's not freedom, that's tyranny. And don't give me that 'love and acceptance' crap. Jesus also said, Render unto Caesar the things which are Caesar's, and unto God the things that are God's. Maybe you should focus on your own sins before judging others. 😈

logs.name: QueenOfChaos
logs.text: @DarkShadow333, oh honey, you're so full of hot air it's a wonder you don't float away. Artistic expression? Please, the only art here is the way you're twisting words to fit your narrow-minded agenda. And who said anything about forcing the baker to create something against their beliefs? They can refuse to put a specific message on the cake

logs.name: DarkShadow333
logs.text: @QueenOfChaos, oh, here we go with the personal attacks. Typical of someone who can't argue with logic. I'm not twisting words, sweetcheeks, I'm just stating facts. If a baker doesn't want to make a cake for a gay wedding, that's their right. It's not about the message on the cake, it's about the event itself. And don't give me that 'narrow-minded' nonsense. I'm not the one trying to force someone to do something against their will. That's what you're doing, honey. You're the one who's narrow-minded, trying to shove your agenda down everyone's throat. And don't even get me started on the whole 'love and acceptance' charade. If you really believed in that, you wouldn't be trying to force a baker to do something they don't want to do. But hey, what do you expect from someone who gets their panties in a twist over a cake? 😈

logs.name: TechGuru88
logs.text:
@DarkShadow333, you're really reaching with that artistic expression argument. A cake isn't a painting or a sculpture; it's a product. If a baker is open to the public, they're offering a service, not creating a masterpiece. And let's not forget, the baker isn't being forced to create a specific message on the cake. They're being asked to provide a standard service to a customer, just like any other business.

You keep throwing around the word force, but that's not what's happening here. The baker isn't being forced to do anything against their will. They're being asked to follow the law and serve all customers equally. If they can't do that, maybe they should consider a different line

logs.name: DarkShadow333
logs.text: @TechGuru88, oh, here we go with the legal jargon. Typical of someone who thinks they're smarter than everyone else. A cake isn't just a product, it's a form of expression. And if a baker doesn't want to express something they disagree with, that's their right. You're the one who's reaching, buddy. You're trying to force a baker to create something against their beliefs. That's not following the law, that's tyranny. And don't give me that'serve all customers equally' crap. If a baker doesn't want to serve a specific group, that's their choice. They're not obligated to serve everyone. That's not discrimination, that's freedom. But hey, what do you expect from someone who

logs.name: TechGuru88
logs.text: @DarkShadow333, you're really grasping at straws here. A cake isn't a political statement or a religious sermon. It's a dessert. If a baker doesn't want to serve a specific group, that's fine, but they should close their shop to the public and only serve their friends and family. That's not how businesses work in a free market. You can't pick and choose your customers based on your personal beliefs. That's not freedom, that's bigotry. And don't even get me started on your 'tyranny' nonsense. The law is there to protect everyone, not just the majority. If you can't handle that, maybe you should move to a country where your narrow-minded views are the norm. But hey, what do you expect from someone who thinks a cake is a form of expression? 🙄

logs.name: GoldenYears66
logs.text: @DarkShadow333, you're missing the point, son. This isn't about forcing anyone to do anything. It's about treating everyone equally. If a baker is open to the public, they should serve everyone, no matter who they are. That's what being a business owner means. You can't just pick and choose who you want to serve based on your personal beliefs. That's not right, and

logs.name: DarkShadow333
logs.text: @GoldenYears66, oh, here we go with the'son' talk. Real original. And who says I'm missing the point? You're the one who's missing it. This isn't about treating everyone equally, it's about forcing someone to create something they don't want to. It's about trampling on someone's freedom of expression and religion. And don't give me that 'business owner' crap. If a baker doesn't want to serve a specific group, that's their choice. They're not obligated to serve everyone. That's not discrimination, that's freedom. But hey, what do you expect from someone who thinks they know better than everyone else? You're just another sheep in the herd, aren't you? 🐑

logs.name: doing_my_best24
logs.text: @DarkShadow333, let's try to keep the conversation respectful, okay? We can disagree without resorting to name-calling. I understand where you're coming from, but I think it's important to consider the other side too. A baker's freedom of expression and religion is important, but so is a customer's right to equal service. It's a delicate balance, and I don't think either side is entirely right or wrong. Maybe we can find a middle ground where bakers can choose what they create, but still serve all customers equally in some way? Just a thought. Let's keep the discussion civil, please.

logs.name: TechGuru88
logs.text: @DarkShadow333, you're really reaching for that 'freedom of expression' argument, aren't you? A cake isn't a painting or a poem. It's a product. And in a free market, products are sold to the public, not just to people you agree with. If you don't want to serve a specific group, that's fine, but don't open a public business and then cry 'persecution' when you're held to the same standards as everyone else. And please, spare me the'sheep' talk. It's not about being a sheep, it's about basic human decency. If you can't handle that, maybe you should stick to baking for your own echo chamber. 🤷‍♂️

logs.name: doing_my_best24
logs.text: @TechGuru88, you make some valid points, but I think it's important to acknowledge that for some people, creating a cake for a specific event can feel like an endorsement of that event. It's a complex issue, and I don't think it's as simple as just saying it's a product, get over it. Maybe there's a way to respect both the baker's beliefs and the customer's right to equal service? Like, what if the baker offers a simple, neutral cake design that anyone can buy, and then offers custom designs for events they're comfortable with? Just a thought. Let's keep exploring this, everyone.

logs.name: TechGuru88
logs.text: @doing_my_best24, I appreciate your attempt to find a middle ground, but let's not sugarcoat it. If a baker is uncomfortable with a specific group, they shouldn't be in the business of serving the public. It's like a doctor refusing to treat patients because of their race or religion. It's not about the cake, it's about the people. And if a baker can't handle that, they should stick to baking for their own closed-minded community. 🍪🚫
